Message.Title: Ichan deal offers huge upside.
Message.Msg: The deal that Ichan presents to Dell shareholders offers huge potential upside.As I under it, the deal offers two options {1} $12 cash and retain your Dell shares in the form of a stub or {2} forego the $12 cash payment and convert yout shares to a stub on a ratio of 7.27 shares and thus end up with 8.27 new Dell stub shares. Ichan and Southwest have stated that they plan to persue option 2 According to the offer the Stub could earn between $0.50-$0.89 per share..Applying a 6 multiple gives value of $3.00 to $5.34 or $24.80 to $44.16 per Dell share.While entirely theoritical.one cannot deny that the Ichan offer gives Dell shareholders a huge upside potential as an alternative to giviing all the future upside to Michael Dell.
Does Icahn make an official offer yet? Is he required to make detailed layout of his financial arrangement for buyout?

Message.Title: Icahn's buyout deal?
Message.Msg: Icahn's current proposal skeptically. Icahn has yet (it has been a week since his announcement last week) to submit a formal, fully financed offer for the special committee run by Dell's board of directors to evaluate.
Dells balance sheet is starting to bleed and with the so called transformation very many folks are going to be left without a job.

Topic.Title: prepare for a life after earnings

Message.Msg: And not to mention how many employees will be let go

His earnings estimate assumes only 20% of the current shareholders take stock in lieu of the $12 cash dividend. I think that number will be higher, maybe even closer to 50% which means there will be alot more shares outstandings and EPS will be lower (of course the flip side of that is that Icahn doesn't need to use as much debt and/or cash to pay the dividend, so the balance sheet will look better). Irregardless, if Michael Dell wants to keep his company (and who wouldn't), he is probably busy right now talking with Silver Lake or Microsoft about inje cting additional money and raising his offer price. IMO, his current offer will not pass. But an offer at $15 or more I think would get the needed votes.
Just as food for thought, one year ago the stock price was $14.70, two years ago $15.66, three years ago $14.83, so raising their bid to somewhere between $14.70 and $15.66 takes the cake.
